Description: Elder (Sambucus nigra) is a tall flowering 
 shrub with clusters of white, fragrant flowers in late 
 Spring and red berries in early autumn. It has a long 
 history of uses as a source of food, for hedgerows, 
 for keeping insects (and perhaps the Devil) at bay, 
 and a host of other uses. Often Found: Elder is most often found in the 
 British Isles in hedgerows and along the edges 
 of fields, woodlands and sometimes scrub areas. Eating Common Beech: This is the simpler, non
-alcoholic version of Elderflower Champagne without 
 the fizz or the time required. 
 You will need: 
 - 10-15 elderflower heads 
 - 2 lemons 
 - 1-1.5Liters of water 
 - 800g-1kg of granulated sugar 
 - A selection of bottles with lids 
 Method: 
 1. Pick your elderflower heads 2. Boil the water and stir in the sugar to dissolve 
 3. Add the lemon â€“ some people prefer to zest and 
 juice the lemons, others to slice and throw them in. 
 4. Take the water off the boil and add the elderflower 
 heads. 
 5. Cover and leave to stand for 24-48hrs, stirring every 
 12hrs or so with a clean wooden spoon. 
 6. Strain the resulting mixture through muslin 
 or sieve and decant into clean bottles. 
 Glass or plastic should work fine as long as they 
 have been properly cleaned/sterilised. 
 7. Drink on its own (for the dedicated), dilute (for the majority) 
 or add to other drinks and concoctions as you see fit. 
 It will be usable for weeks but be wary of anything 
 that has been bottled for too long.
